title: r2dii.plot
text: Quick plots allow create good looking plot without extensive knowledge R packages. perfect quick look data users interested standard PACTA visualizations. common characteristics : 5 year time span. Formatted data labels. Formatted axis labels scales. title (subtitle). Use qplot_emission_intensity() sda-like data.  Use qplot_trajectory() market_share-like data.  Use qplot_techmix() market_share-like data.
code: data <- matched %>%   target_sda(abcd, co2_intensity_scenario = scenario, region_isos = region) %>%   filter(     sector == "cement",     region == "global",     scenario_source == "demo_2020"   ) #> Warning: Removing rows in abcd where `emission_factor` is NA  qplot_emission_intensity(data) data <- matched %>%   target_market_share(abcd, scenario = scenario_demo_2020, region_isos = region) %>%   filter(     technology == "renewablescap",     region == "global",     scenario_source == "demo_2020"   )  qplot_trajectory(data) data <- matched %>%   target_market_share(abcd, scenario = scenario_demo_2020, region_isos = region) %>%   filter(     sector == "power",     region == "global",     scenario_source == "demo_2020",     metric %in% c("projected", "corporate_economy", "target_sds")   )  qplot_techmix(data) #> The `technology_share` values are plotted for extreme years. #> Do you want to plot different years? E.g. filter . with:`subset(., year %in% c(2020, 2030))`.

title: r2dii.plot
text: Plots created plot_*() functions show data . customize plots can use three strategies: Use parameters plot_*() functions, Modify input data, Use ggplot2 functions. following sub sections show three strategies applied different functions plot_*() family.

what: Plot customization strategies 1 and 3: parameters and ggplot2 functions
title: r2dii.plot
text: show might customize plot using strategy 1 3 based plot_emission_intensity(). basic output function looks rather unappealing.  can use parameters prep_emission_intensity plot_emission_intensity() replicate features qplot_emission_intensity() (strategy 1), add plot labels ggplot2::labs() (strategy 3).
code: data <- matched %>%   target_sda(abcd, co2_intensity_scenario = scenario, region_isos = region) %>%   filter(     sector == "cement",     region == "global",     scenario_source == "demo_2020"   ) #> Warning: Removing rows in abcd where `emission_factor` is NA  data <- prep_emission_intensity(data)  plot_emission_intensity(data) data <- matched %>%   target_sda(abcd, co2_intensity_scenario = scenario, region_isos = region) %>%   filter(     sector == "cement",     region == "global",     scenario_source == "demo_2020"   ) #> Warning: Removing rows in abcd where `emission_factor` is NA  data <- prep_emission_intensity(data, convert_label = to_title, span_5yr = TRUE)  plot_emission_intensity(data) +   labs(     title = "Emission Intensity Trend for the Cement Sector",     x = "Year",     y = "Tons of CO2 per Ton of Production Unit"   )

what: Plot customization strategies 2 and 3: input data and ggplot2 functions
title: r2dii.plot
text: can also polish plot modifying input data (strategy 2), example: Changing time span. Adding custom labels adding column ‘label’ ‘label_tech’ market_share-like data. modifying output ggplot object (strategy 3), example: Adding title subtitle using ggplot2::labs(). Changing x y axis labels using ggplot2::labs(). Customizing colours legend labels ggplot2::scale_colour_manual() r2dii.plot::scale_*() functions (see Styling functions). might customize three kinds plots using strategy 2 3: plot_emission_intensity() - add custom title axis labels modify colours legend labels.  plot_trajectory() - change time span, add ‘label’ column add custom title axis labels.  plot_techmix() - change time span, add ‘label’ column, apply custom colours modify legend labels.  plot_techmix() - remove scenario data start year.
code: data <- sda %>%   filter(     sector == "cement",     region == "global",     scenario_source == "demo_2020",     year <= 2030   )  data <- prep_emission_intensity(data)  plot_emission_intensity(data) +   labs(     title = "Emission intensity plot for cement",     x = "Time",     y = "Tons of CO2 per ton of cement produced"   ) +   scale_color_manual(     values = c("#4a5e54", "#a63d57", "#78c4d6", "#f2e06e"),     labels = c("Proj.", "Corp. Economy", "Target (demo)", "Adj. Scenario (demo)")   ) #> Scale for colour is already present. #> Adding another scale for colour, which will replace the existing scale. data <- matched %>%   target_market_share(abcd, scenario = scenario_demo_2020, region_isos = region) %>%   filter(     technology == "renewablescap",     region == "global",     scenario_source == "demo_2020",     year <= 2030   ) %>%   mutate(     label = case_when(       metric == "projected" ~ "Your Portfolio",       metric == "corporate_economy" ~ "Benchmark (Corp. Economy)",       metric == "target_sds" ~ "Sustainable Development Scen.",       metric == "target_sps" ~ "Stated Policies Scen.",       metric == "target_cps" ~ "Current Policy Scen.",       TRUE ~ metric     )   )  data <- prep_trajectory(data)  plot_trajectory(data) +   scale_x_continuous(n.breaks = 3) +   labs(     title = "Portfolio Scenario Alignment for Renewables Technology",     x = "Year",     y = "Production normalized to start year"   ) +   theme(plot.margin = unit(c(0.5, 6, 0.5, 1), "cm")) # so the long labels fit #> Scale for x is already present. #> Adding another scale for x, which will replace the existing scale. data <- market_share %>%   filter(     metric %in% c("projected", "corporate_economy", "target_sds"),     sector == "power",     scenario_source == "demo_2020",     region == "global",     year >= 2021,     year <= 2040 # custom time range   ) %>%   mutate(     label = case_when(       metric == "projected" ~ "Your Portfolio",       metric == "corporate_economy" ~ "Corporate Economy Benchmark",       metric == "target_sds" ~ "SDS Scenario"     )   )  data <- prep_techmix(data) #> The `technology_share` values are plotted for extreme years. #> Do you want to plot different years? E.g. filter data with:`subset(data, year %in% c(2020, 2030))`.  plot_techmix(data) +   scale_fill_manual(     values = c("black", "brown", "grey", "yellow", "blue", "green4"),     labels = paste(c("Coal", "Oil", "Gas", "Nuclear", "Hydro", "Renewables"), "Cap.")   ) #> Scale for fill is already present. #> Adding another scale for fill, which will replace the existing scale. data <- market_share %>%   filter(     metric %in% c("projected", "corporate_economy", "target_sds"),     sector == "power",     region == "global",     scenario_source == "demo_2020"   ) %>%   filter(     !((metric == "target_sds") & (year == 2020))   )  data <- prep_techmix(data) #> The `technology_share` values are plotted for extreme years. #> Do you want to plot different years? E.g. filter data with:`subset(data, year %in% c(2020, 2030))`.  plot_techmix(data)

title: r2dii.plot
text: number functions allow customize plots using 2DII style: Use theme_2dii() change display non-data content.  Use scale_colour_r2dii() scale_fill_r2dii() apply 2DII colour palette (see ?scale_colour_2dii() find available colour labels).  Use scale_colour_r2dii_sector() scale_fill_r2dii_sector() apply 2DII colour palette sectors (see ?scale_colour_2dii_sector() find available colour labels).  Use scale_colour_r2dii_tech() scale_fill_r2dii_tech() apply 2DII colour palette technologies (see ?scale_colour_2dii_tech() find available colour labels).
code: data <- market_share %>%   filter(     metric == "projected",     sector == "power",     region == "global",     year %in% c(2020, 2025)   )  ggplot(data, aes(x = factor(year), y = production)) +   geom_col() +   facet_wrap(~technology) +   theme_2dii() data <- market_share %>%   filter(     metric != "corporate_economy",     sector == "power",     region == "global",     technology == "renewablescap"   )  ggplot(data, aes(x = year, y = production, color = metric)) +   geom_line() +   scale_colour_r2dii(labels = c("dark_blue", "green", "orange", "ruby_red")) +   theme_2dii() data <- market_share %>%   filter(     metric == "projected",     region == "global",     year %in% c(2020, 2025)   ) %>%   group_by(sector, year) %>%   summarise(production = sum(production)) #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'sector'. You can override using the #> `.groups` argument.  ggplot(data, aes(x = factor(year), y = production, fill = sector)) +   geom_col() +   scale_fill_r2dii_sector(sectors = c("automotive", "oil&gas", "power")) +   theme_2dii() +   facet_wrap(~sector) technologies <- c("coalcap", "oilcap", "gascap", "nuclearcap", "hydrocap", "renewablescap")  data <- market_share %>%   filter(     metric == "projected",     sector == "power",     region == "global",     year %in% c(2020, 2025)   ) %>%   mutate(technology = factor(technology, levels = technologies)) %>%   arrange(technology)  ggplot(data, aes(x = factor(year), y = production, fill = technology)) +   geom_col() +   scale_fill_r2dii_tech("power", technologies) +   facet_wrap(~technology) +   theme_2dii()
